Galaxy-Galaxy Strong Lensing with U-Net (GGSL-UNet). I. Extracting 2-Dimensional Information from Multi-Band Images in Ground and Space Observations

Fucheng Zhong School of Physics and Astronomy, Sun Yat-sen University, Zhuhai Campus, 2 Daxue Road, Xiangzhou District, Zhuhai, 519082, P. R. China Ruibiao Luo Purple Mountain Observatory, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing 210023, P. R. China Nicola R. Napolitano Department of Physics E. Pancini, University Federico II, Via Cinthia 21, I-80126, Naples, Italy INAF – Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy Crescenzo Tortora INAF – Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy Rui Li Institude for Astrophysics, School of Physics, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, 450001, China Xincheng Zhu Department of Astronomy, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Valerio Busillo Department of Physics E. Pancini, University Federico II, Via Cinthia 21, I-80126, Naples, Italy INAF – Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy L. V. E. Koopmans Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen, P.O.Box 800, 9700AV Groningen, the Netherlands Giuseppe Longo Department of Physics E. Pancini, University Federico II, Via Cinthia 21, I-80126, Naples, Italy
Abstract

We present a novel deep learning method to separately extract the two-dimensional flux information of the foreground galaxy (deflector) and background system (source) of Galaxy-Galaxy Strong Lensing events using U-Net (GGSL-Unet for short). In particular, the segmentation of the source image is found to enhance the performance of the lens modeling, especially for ground-based images. By combining mock lens foreground+background components with real sky survey noise to train the GGSL-Unet, we show it can correctly model the input image noise and extract the lens signal. However, the most important result of this work is that the GGSL-UNet can accurately reconstruct real ground-based lensing systems from the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS) in one second. We also test the GGSL-UNet on space-based (HST) lenses from BELLS GALLERY, and obtain comparable accuracy of standard lens modeling tools. Finally, we calculate the magnitudes from the reconstructed deflector and source images and use this to derive photometric redshifts (photo-z𝑧zitalic_z), with the photo-z𝑧zitalic_z of the deflector well consistent with spectroscopic ones. This first work, demonstrates the great potential of the generative network for lens finding, image denoising, source segmentation, and decomposing and modeling of strong lensing systems. For the upcoming ground- and space-based surveys, the GGSL-UNet can provide high-quality images as well as geometry and redshift information for precise lens modeling, in combination with classical MCMC modeling for best accuracy in the galaxy-galaxy strong lensing analysis.

galaxy-galaxy lens — photometric — deep learning — image reconstruction.

1 Introduction

Galaxy-galaxy lensing (GGL) has become an indispensable tool for studying the evolution of the universe, the nature of dark matter, and the structure and properties of galaxies (Treu, 2010; Hoekstra et al., 2013).

Gravitational lensing is a phenomenon involving foreground galaxies (named lenses or deflectors) and background far-away systems (sources), where the gravitational field of the former total mass component distorts images of these latter systems. Depending on the mass of the deflector and the alignment of the source and the foreground galaxy, the GGL can be either “weak” or “strong.” In the “strong” version of this phenomenon, the lensed image of the sources can exhibit different symmetries depending on the relative positions of the background and foreground galaxies along the line of sight and the intrinsic shape of the source itself: a double or quadruply image or even an “Einstein cross” (in case the four images form a perfect cross) in case the source is a compact system (e.g., a quasar, a galactic nucleus or even a supernova), a closed ring (aka “Einstein ring”) for a perfect alignment, or a semi-arc (Schneider et al., 1992; Wambsganss, 1998) for a certain degree of alignment, in case of a more extended source (e.g., a galaxy). For larger misaligned, the GGL becomes “weak,” producing small deformations of the background sources, of the order of the thousandths of time of the original ellipticity, over large areas around the lens.

The “weak” GGL provides a method for estimating the excess surface density and the halo profile with its statistics (e.g., Clampitt et al. 2017; Luo et al. 2018; Luo et al. 2022; Dvornik et al. 2023; Chaurasiya et al. 2024), helping reconstruct the cluster mass distribution (Bartelmann & Schneider, 2001; Bradač et al., 2005), and constraining the cosmological parameters (Cacciato et al., 2009). The “strongly” lensed and magnified background galaxies, instead, offer a direct way to constraint the Hubble constant through the time delay of source variability (Refsdal, 1964; Koopmans et al., 2003) and investigate very high redshift galaxies during the reionization epoch of the universe (e.g., Coe et al. 2013; Atek et al. 2015; Kawamata et al. 2016; Coe et al. 2019; Windhorst et al. 2023). By incorporating the assumption of dark matter particle interactions on small scales, “strong” GGL can also provide an additional method for constraining different dark matter models (e.g., Gilman et al. 2020, 2021, 2023). Obviously, the lensing phenomenon helps to map the fine details of the mass distribution of the foreground galaxy, such as dark matter substructures (e.g., Vegetti & Koopmans 2009a; Vegetti et al. 2010, 2014), naturally providing strong constraints on its total mass, and dark matter fraction (Koopmans et al., 2006; Gavazzi et al., 2007; Vegetti & Koopmans, 2009b; Auger et al., 2010; Treu, 2010; Tortora et al., 2010; Saha et al., 2024a).

Focusing on the strong lensing, with the advent of the III-Stage sky surveys (e.g., the Kilo Degree Survey, KiDS, de Jong et al. 2013; the DeCAM Legacy Survey, DeCALs, Flaugher et al. 2015; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et al. 2016; the Hyper Suprime Camera Survey, HSC, Aihara et al. 2018) and the upcoming IV-Stage Surveys (e.g., Euclid Laureijs et al. 2011; Vera Rubin Legacy Survey in Space and Time, LSST, Ivezić 2019); the China Space Station Telescope Survey, CSST, Zhan 2011), it has become mandatory to seek for the highest completeness in the lensing search to increase the number of lens targets and achieve statistical significance in scientific analysis, many automated strong lens detection tools have been developed (e.g., Bolton et al. 2006; Sonnenfeld et al. 2013; Gavazzi et al. 2014; Petrillo et al. 2017; Pourrahmani et al. 2018; Petrillo et al. 2019a, b; Li et al. 2020, 2021; Thuruthipilly et al. 2022; Nagam et al. 2023; Thuruthipilly 2024), including both classical methods and deep-learning-based approaches. Thousands of lens candidates have been found, though a small fraction of them have been modeled. Modeling lenses often require images with a high enough Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), such as those from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) in the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS, Bolton et al. 2006, 2008; Shu et al. 2015, 2017) or the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS) for the GALaxy-Lyα𝛼\alphaitalic_α EmitteR sYstems (BELLS GALLERY, Shu et al. 2016), as well as those from the HSC, such as the Survey of Gravitationally-Lensed Objects in HSC Imaging (SuGOHI, Sonnenfeld et al. 2019). However, this process can be time-consuming and often requires empirical initial parameters. Furthermore, it is prone to degeneracies between the parameters of the foreground and background galaxy light, which can bias the mass inference. With the rapid development of generative neural networks, these networks can reconstruct images from given inputs, providing us with a novel way to denoise and model lensing objects. For instance, if we can model the different lens components with high accuracy, one can use the background light only to increase the speed and accuracy of standard MCMC modeling. This will help us to estimate the morphology parameters of the arc (Gentile et al., 2023), as well as the redshift and photometric parameters (Zitrin et al., 2011; Pignataro et al., 2021). To provide these different lens components for the subsequent modeling task, we use U-Net (Ronneberger et al., 2015), a generative deep learning model, to reconstruct noise-reduced images of the foreground and background sources, respectively, from the lens image input.

Using U-Net, we can reduce model dependency in lens modeling, decrease the number of parameters required, model the lens quickly, and provide key information, such as magnitude and photometric redshift (photo-z), for lens modeling. Through the reconstructed image, we can calculate and compare the χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of different components transparently rather than directly obtaining lens parameters via a supervised deep learning model, which often appears as an unknown “black box.” By knowing the flux from different components, we can even trace the foreground total mass using the geometry of the source flux distribution and trace the stellar mass using the foreground flux.

To evaluate the effectiveness of the reconstructed images, χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be calculated in the subsequent analysis. To demonstrate that the model trained on simulation data can be applied to real data, dozens of real lens images, including lens candidates from KiDS with corresponding spectroscopy measurements and BELLS GALLERY lenses from HST with modeling (see §2.2), are used as test samples. We also compare the reconstructed results with those obtained using the previous method based on Markov-Chain-Monte-Carlo (MCMC).

The contents of this paper are as follows: §2 introduces the dataset, including both simulated and real data. §3 covers the basic concept and technical details of reconstruction using U-Net. §4 presents the training results, the reconstructions on mock and real lenses, and a comparison with previous methods. In §C, we provide an example of a downstream task: predicting photometric redshift using the reconstructed images as input. Finally, in §5, some discussions and conclusions are provided.

2 Data

The main aim of this work is to train a UNet to accurately separate the signal from the lens, from the source, and the noise of a strong GGL system. In this section, we discuss the best strategies we have decided to adopt to efficiently train our Galaxy-Galaxy Strong Lensing with U-Net (GGSL-UNet here after) tool and the data used for the network’s training and testing phases.

2.1 Real or mock training samples?

There are a few thousand strong GGL candidates cataloged by different observational programs, such as SLACS (mentioned above), Strong Lensing Legacy Survey (SL2S, Sonnenfeld et al. 2013), HSC lens candidates (Sonnenfeld et al., 2018; Cañameras et al., 2021; Shu et al., 2022), DES (Nord et al., 2016; Diehl et al., 2017; Jacobs et al., 2019), DECALS (Huang et al., 2020, 2021; Stein et al., 2022; Storfer et al., 2022), and KiDS (Petrillo et al., 2019c; Li et al., 2020, 2021). The latest and largest catalogs have been more and more based on deep-learning techniques based on photometric data (for instance, Petrillo et al. 2017; Li et al. 2020) or even spectroscopy data (see Li et al. 2019, and GaSNet Zhong et al. 2022). Despite the large amount of high-quality candidates collected, these are insufficient to be directly used as the training set for DL models as they are far fewer than the requirements for DL model training. More importantly, it is impossible to define robust enough model parameters for them to be used as “ground truth” for network training. The parameters of modeled lenses are derived from certain codes, which might introduce systematic biases inherent to the code rather than totally reflecting the ground truth. These biases could be learned and inherited by the network trained on such data.

Using simulated lenses as training data is one way to solve this problem. Combining mock foreground and background sources with real sky survey image noise cutouts can produce data with realistic noise. By designing the network to fit the mock and the real noise components, one can expect to reconstruct the different components of both mock and real lenses. The critical point is that if the network can fit the real noise component very well, even when a mock or not fully realistic component is used in the training data, we can expect the rest of the components to be the signal we want after noise fitting. We can produce the lens images within the specified observation conditions and cover as many major physical situations as possible. In the next subsection, we introduce the main observation datasets that used in this paper.

2.2 Observation data and high-quality strong lens candidates

As anticipated, this paper focuses on two main datasets: KiDS and BELLS GALLERY. For this latter sample, we have specifically used the ones performed within the BELLS GALLERY sample as reference model performance. The main reason to choose KiDS is that this dataset provides some of the best image quality data (FWHM∼0.7′′similar-toabsentsuperscript0.7′′\sim 0.7^{\prime\prime}∼ 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in r−limit-from𝑟r-italic_r -band, see also below) currently available from ground observations and very similar pixel-scale to the one expected for the upcoming LSST observation. As such, we can use this dataset to prepare for the early LSST data strong lensing analyses. As we have discussed earlier, ground-based strong lensing systems are particularly challenging due to the higher mixing among the contribution of the light coming from the lens and the background light that introduces further degeneracies on top of the usual strong lensing model alone (Saha et al., 2024b). HST observations, on the other hand, due to their extraordinary image quality (typical FWHM∼0.1′′similar-toabsentsuperscript0.1′′\sim 0.1^{\prime\prime}∼ 0.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), provide a unique opportunity to fully validate our method, pushing it to the most extreme accuracy needed to optimize the image reconstruction of the lensing system and leave no residuals above the very low background of space observations. Below, we summarize the data used and their parent observations.

2.2.1 KiDS data

The Kilo-Degree Survey (KiDS, de Jong et al. 2013) has been carried out using the OmegaCAM (Kuijken, 2011) mounted at the VLT Survey Telescope (VST; Capaccioli & Schipani 2011). It has covered an area of 1350 deg2superscriptdeg2\rm deg^{2}roman_deg start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the equatorial and southern sky in four (u⁢g⁢r⁢i𝑢𝑔𝑟𝑖ugriitalic_u italic_g italic_r italic_i) optical bands (see Wright et al. 2025 for a summary of the final data release observations). The field-of-view of OmegaCam is 1 deg2superscriptdeg2\rm deg^{2}roman_deg start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with 0.2′′/pixelsuperscript0.2′′pixel0.2^{\prime\prime}/\rm pixel0.2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / roman_pixel resolution (after final calibrated, coadded images), and the best image quality observations (FWHM∼0.7′′similar-toabsentsuperscript0.7′′\sim 0.7^{\prime\prime}∼ 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) obtained in r𝑟ritalic_r-band, used as reference filter for weak lensing observations. The optical observations from KiDS have been fully replicated within the VIKING project using the VIRCAM at the VISTA telescope (Edge et al., 2013) in the near-infrared (NIR) bands (Z⁢Y⁢J⁢H⁢KS𝑍𝑌𝐽𝐻subscript𝐾𝑆ZYJHK_{S}italic_Z italic_Y italic_J italic_H italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). To simulate lens images for ground-based telescopes such as KiDS, we needed to reproduce low SNR conditions and a noisy background realistically. To do that (see also §2.3), the noise component is directly taken from KiDS survey images by randomly selecting noise “cutouts” centers in the KiDS footprint. In particular, we have selected 100 000 of these cutouts by checking that there were no pathological situations111This has been done by checking the statistics of the mean and rms values of the pixel counts in the cutouts. (e.g., stellar spikes, bright objects), but yet allowing for the presence of “companion sources” rather than using fully “empty” areas to consider the presence or random source in the field of view in training (see also §2.3 and last columns in Fig. 1).

As a test sample, on the other hand, to be used after the GGSL-UNet has been trained to check the performance for application to real data, we will use the high-quality candidates of real strong gravitational lenses from the catalogs of (Petrillo et al., 2017, 2019a, 2019b) 222https://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids/full_left.html and Li et al. (2020) derived from Fourth KiDS Data Release (DR4; Kuijken et al. 2019). To select strong lens samples from KiDS, we follow two basic criteria. First, we keep the samples with the obvious structures of strong lensing cases, such as arcs or multiple images around the lens. Second, we select the cases matched with spectroscopic survey catalogs, such as SDSS (Bolton et al., 2012; Smee et al., 2013; Dawson et al., 2016), GAMA (Hill et al., 2011; Driver et al., 2011), and MUSE (Napolitano et al., 2020), which can provide precise spectroscopic redshifts (spec-z) for foreground galaxies. We finally identified 50 high-quality KiDS strong lens candidates, with their basic information shown in Table 1. This Table provides the 𝐵𝑃𝑍𝐵𝑃𝑍\it BPZitalic_BPZ (Benítez, 2000, 2011) photometric redshift estimates based on 9-band (u⁢g⁢r⁢i⁢Z⁢Y⁢J⁢H⁢KS𝑢𝑔𝑟𝑖𝑍𝑌𝐽𝐻subscript𝐾𝑆ugriZYJHK_{S}italic_u italic_g italic_r italic_i italic_Z italic_Y italic_J italic_H italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) photometric data from KiDS+VIKING, derived using the Gaussian Aperture and Photometry (GAaP; Kuijken 2008) flux method. It also lists the spectroscopic redshifts (spec-z) of the 50 candidates, obtained by matching to different spectroscopic surveys, in Table 1. The details of strong lensing analysis for the 50 cases will be presented in another paper (Luo et al. in prep) in the future. Here, we focus on the decoupling and photo-z estimation of foreground galaxies and arcs from background sources in this paper.

2.2.2 HST data

As space-based observations, we use the lenses from the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS) for the GALaxy-Lyα𝛼\alphaitalic_α EmitteR sYstems (BELLS GALLERY, Shu et al. 2016). This is chosen because it provides complete foreground and background modeling, which can be used to assess the performance of our GGSL-UNet. It consists of 17 r𝑟ritalic_r-band lens systems whose images will be used as test samples to compare with the GGSL-UNet reconstructed images. The lenses in this sample have been identified using a spectroscopic method that detects the presence of anomalous emission lines from higher redshift galaxies superimposed on the spectra of luminous red galaxies (LRGs). The massive galaxies typically targeted by BOSS spectroscopy are at redshifts z∼similar-to\sim∼0.5-0.8. The emission lines, primarily [OII] λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ3727, Hβ𝛽\betaitalic_β, and [OIII] λ⁢λ𝜆𝜆\lambda\lambdaitalic_λ italic_λ4959,5007, originate from star-forming regions of background galaxies at higher redshifts (z∼similar-to\sim∼1-1.5) that are gravitationally lensed by the foreground LRGs. Regarding the modeling approach, we can benefit from the results of Shu et al. 2016 that have used the modeling tool l⁢f⁢i⁢tg⁢u⁢i𝑙𝑓𝑖subscript𝑡𝑔𝑢𝑖lfit_{gui}italic_l italic_f italic_i italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g italic_u italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a graphical user interface (GUI) to smoothly analyze the BELLS GALLERY lenses using HST F606W-band images with manual feature masks. The tool simultaneously fits the lens light (elliptical Sérsic profiles), the mass parameters (SIE with external shear), and source light (Sérsic or pixelated profiles) to the HST imaging data. A B-spline fitting is also applied to refine the background subtraction and source representation. Finally, an MCMC optimization has been applied to constrain the lens and source positions, flux ratios, and Einstein radii by minimizing the χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT between the ray tracing model and the pixel data of the HST images. This approach balances efficiency with flexibility, yielding lens models and source reconstructions.

2.3 Mock lens

As discussed in §2.1, we only use mock lens images as the training set. The flux of each pixel in a mock lens image is labeled as Iisubscript𝐼𝑖I_{i}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is constructed from three different components:

where Ifsubscript𝐼𝑓I_{f}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the component of the foreground lens galaxy, Ibsubscript𝐼𝑏I_{b}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the component of the background source, and Insubscript𝐼𝑛I_{n}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the noise component sampled from sky survey images with empty centers. The Greek letters α,β,γ,ϵ𝛼𝛽𝛾italic-ϵ\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\epsilonitalic_α , italic_β , italic_γ , italic_ϵ are the random values sampled from a uniform distribution during the training process, which is deemed as an online augmentation (Shorten & Khoshgoftaar, 2019, see also §3 for more details). We stress here that Eq. 1, being defined pixel by pixel, encodes the fact that in lensing events, there is potential for a contribution from both the foreground and the background signal that cannot be sharply separated. This is prone to degeneracies among the different contributions that are harder to break for large spatial overlaps between the two components. This is the typical situation we have for ground-based observations with poorer seeing. We have tried to mitigate this situation in constructing our tool, as we will detail in §3. The magnitude of the noise, α⁢β⁢ϵ𝛼𝛽italic-ϵ\alpha\beta\epsilonitalic_α italic_β italic_ϵ, ensures that the noise is statistically more minor than the foreground and background signals. The tuned three different components are defined as:

which are used as labeled images in training to identify the foreground, background, and noise pixels. It is necessary to ensure correct segmentation in the lens components.

The subscripts represent abbreviations for the image’s color band, row, and column. As an example, for a cutout image with four different wavelength bands (u,g,r,i)𝑢𝑔𝑟𝑖(u,g,r,i)( italic_u , italic_g , italic_r , italic_i ) and a size of 64×64646464\times 6464 × 64, the image subscripts should be:

Each band has corresponding randomly chosen magnitudes or slopes (represented by the Greek letters). Here, α=α(band,1,1)𝛼subscript𝛼band11\alpha=\alpha_{\rm(band,1,1)}italic_α = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_band , 1 , 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the other Greek letters are also 4-dimensional vectors sampled from a uniform distribution. The range of the uniform distribution is shown in Table 2. Note that the flat priors in these training parameters of Table correspond to a flat prior to the colors, which we have deliberately chosen because we wanted the network to reconstruct the lens based on its geometry rather than use the color information. This will ensure no color biases are introduced in the reconstruction of different bands.

The foreground and background images in four different bands share the same ellipticity and effective radius. In real cases, the effective radius or Sérsic index might vary across different bands, which we approximate by tuning parameters such as α𝛼\alphaitalic_α and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ. The foreground models in different bands differ in magnitude and slope (α,γ𝛼𝛾\alpha,\gammaitalic_α , italic_γ). Because the background source is a smaller, more compact object with a smaller effective radius, we did not consider its slope change for simplicity compared to the foreground. Therefore, the difference between the background models in different bands is only in magnitude (α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\betaitalic_α , italic_β) and does not involve any slope (γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ) tuning for simplicity. We remind you that the noise is randomly sampled from the reference dataset (KiDS or HST in our case) with no source in the center but with no restriction on the presence of other sources off-center. This also allows us to include possible “companion” or “contaminant” sources in the training sample, reproducing realistic observational conditions that might or might not involve overlapping sources blended within the signal from the strong lensing components. The foreground and background images are normalized by their maximum values, while the noise is normalized by its median value. Using these augmentations has two advantages. First, it can reduce the volume of training data. Second, the training data can explore a more expansive parameter space; the amplitude and slope parameters can tune the color information while the geometric information remains unchanged.

To mock the foreground deflector and background sources, we have used a single Sérsic profile (Ciotti & Bertin, 1999; MacArthur et al., 2003). Although this is not the most realistic model we can use to reproduce more complex multicomponent systems, this has been shown to capture most of the galaxy properties and provide a good approximation to produce training samples for deep learning tools that have successfully applied to real galaxies (see, e.g., the measurement of structural parameters, Li et al. 2022). To generalize the typical strong lensing configurations for the foreground system, we have also considered a “blending” situation where twenty percent of the deflector is constituted by a pair of galaxies with two different Sérsic models and centers slight offset within one θEsubscript𝜃𝐸\theta_{E}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, to train the U-Net to consider the cases of false detections, we randomly set 5% of the training set made of Fb=0subscript𝐹𝑏0F_{b}=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 (i.e., no-background signal) to help the U-Net to recognize cases without true galaxy background signal.

We used 𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑠𝑡𝑟𝑜𝑛𝑜𝑚𝑦𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑠𝑡𝑟𝑜𝑛𝑜𝑚𝑦\it{lenstronomy}italic_lenstronomy (Birrer & Amara, 2018) to simulate the foreground and the distorted background source. The (flux normalized) Sérsic model is defined as:

I⁢(ξ)=exp⁡{−bn⁢ξ1/n}⊗P⁢S⁢F,𝐼𝜉tensor-productsubscript𝑏𝑛superscript𝜉1𝑛𝑃𝑆𝐹\displaystyle I(\xi)=\exp\{-b_{n}\xi^{1/n}\}\otimes PSF,italic_I ( italic_ξ ) = roman_exp { - italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ⊗ italic_P italic_S italic_F , (6)
ξ=R/Rh,bn=2⁢n−1/3,formulae-sequence𝜉𝑅subscript𝑅ℎsubscript𝑏𝑛2𝑛13\displaystyle\xi=R/R_{h},\ b_{n}=2n-1/3,italic_ξ = italic_R / italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 italic_n - 1 / 3 , (7)
R=q⁢x2+y2/q.𝑅𝑞superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦2𝑞\displaystyle R=\sqrt{qx^{2}+y^{2}/q}.italic_R = square-root start_ARG italic_q italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_q end_ARG . (8)

We can identify the following parameters: the radius R𝑅Ritalic_R, from the center, (xl,yl)subscript𝑥𝑙subscript𝑦𝑙(x_{l},y_{l})( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ); the half-light radius, Rhsubscript𝑅ℎR_{h}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; the position angle, P⁢A𝑃𝐴PAitalic_P italic_A; the Sérsic index, n𝑛nitalic_n; the axis ratio, q𝑞qitalic_q. The parameters for the foreground and the background Sérsic profiles are shown in Table 2. We used flat distributions for all parameters to avoid an unbalanced training sample and a realistic range of intrinsic parameters, as suggested from the real data (see, e.g., the BELL GALLERY, Shu et al. 2016). As a first proof-of-concept test, in this paper, we cover a reasonable volume of the physical parameter space of the lensing systems, despite this might not fully consider all possible parameters, including extreme cases (for example, we are excluding very flat foreground systems with q∼0.2−0.3similar-to𝑞0.20.3q\sim 0.2-0.3italic_q ∼ 0.2 - 0.3). This option makes the network training more efficient, fast, and easier to converge while improving performance within the primary parameter space. Although the parameter space has been chosen to optimize the model training, the testing step in the following section shows that the GGSL-Unet still performs excellently in most mock/real lens test cases, as quantified by the chi-squares diagnostic. The projected potential of the background galaxy is calculated according to a singular isothermal ellipsoid profile (SIE, Kormann et al. 1994), which shares the same geometry parameters, like center, P⁢A𝑃𝐴PAitalic_P italic_A, and q𝑞qitalic_q, as the foreground Sérsic model. The convergence (or dimensionless surface density) for SIE is defined as:

κ⁢(x,y)=12⁢θEq⁢x2+y2/q,𝜅𝑥𝑦12subscript𝜃𝐸𝑞superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦2𝑞\displaystyle\kappa(x,y)=\frac{1}{2}\frac{\theta_{E}}{\sqrt{qx^{2}+y^{2}/q}},italic_κ ( italic_x , italic_y ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_q italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_q end_ARG end_ARG , (9)

where θEsubscript𝜃𝐸\theta_{E}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Einstein radius. The synthesis of the background galaxy will be sheared by large-scale external perturbations. This external shear is separated into two shear components, γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and γ2subscript𝛾2\gamma_{2}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, along the radial and tangential directions. In Table 2, we list the domain of these parameters in the bottom rows. The foreground and distorted background images are then convolved with a Gaussian Point Spread Function (PSF). For the KiDS-like lensing systems, we have adopted a constant σ=0.4′′𝜎superscript0.4′′\sigma=0.4^{\prime\prime}italic_σ = 0.4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, corresponding to an FWHM ∼0.7′′similar-toabsentsuperscript0.7′′\sim 0.7^{\prime\prime}∼ 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the average seeing for the r𝑟ritalic_r-band in KiDS and very close to the median seeing of the HQ strong lensing candidates in g𝑔gitalic_g- and i𝑖iitalic_i-band (∼0.8′′similar-toabsentsuperscript0.8′′\sim 0.8^{\prime\prime}∼ 0.8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT)333To save computational resources and storage, we used the same mock parameters/templates across different bands, applying the same σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ for all bands. For instance, we only mock 1x64x64 Ifsubscript𝐼𝑓I_{f}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ibsubscript𝐼𝑏I_{b}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the PSF applied and then adjust the parameters α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, β𝛽\betaitalic_β, γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ to produce images for the four bands. This approach reduces storage and memory usage by 75%, which is beneficial when dealing with more bands (e.g., 9-band images) and large volumes of training data.. Note that for this first experiment, our choice to ignore the (albeit small) band-to-band seeing variation can potentially impact the accuracy of the GGSL-UNet in real applications where a band-to-band seeing variation might be rather common. As we will test the trained network on real observations in §2.2, we will keep this in mind as a possible source of systematics. However, we anticipate here that we will consider this implementation for future analyses (see §5). The PSF and the lower limit of θEsubscript𝜃𝐸\theta_{E}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are driven to optimize the performances on ground-based observations.

Similarly, to predict BELL GALLERY lenses, we have also simulated HST r𝑟ritalic_r-band images, following the same procedure as for KiDS. The noise component is taken from real HST survey images as for KiDS, while the PSF is generated by Tiny Tim (Krist et al., 2011), with a σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ of approximately 0.1′′.

Some examples of mock KiDS-like and HST-like mock strong lensing configurations, generated under different augmentation parameters, are shown in Fig. 1. They include the total lensing system images (first column on the left), the foreground galaxy images (second column), the background images (third column), and noise images (fourth column). The lensing system images are the input of our network, and the foreground, background, and noise images are the ones we want to reconstruct with the GGSL-UNet. The more configurations of mock input images Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are shown in Fig. 2.

Despite the simplified lens model used in our training data, we will show that the network can already reconstruct the lensing system’s different components rather accurately, not only if applied to mock lens images but also to real strong lensing events.

3 Method

We use U-Net to extract the different components of lens images. The U-Net model is a type of generative model consisting of two main branches: down-sampling and up-sampling blocks with shortcuts at the same level. The down-sampling and up-sampling blocks mainly comprise ResNet structure units (He et al., 2015) and transformer structure units (Vaswani et al., 2017). The down-sampling reduces the dimension of features, while the up-sampling increases them. In our case, this means reducing the image’s last two dimensions (see Eq. 5). For instance, the first down-sampling block in Table 3 reduces the input image size from 4×64×64464644\times 64\times 644 × 64 × 64 to 32×32×3232323232\times 32\times 3232 × 32 × 32). We use the Python module diffusers 444https://pypi.org/project/diffusers/ (von Platen et al., 2022) to quickly build a U-Net model, in which the blocks and the channels used are shown in Table 3.

U-Net has been widely applied in image segmentation (Siddique et al., 2020), producing output images of the same size as the input and effectively modeling noise through skip connections in its architecture. Recently, U-Net has also been applied to improve the performance of strong gravitational lens searching (N et al., 2024) and modeling (Ostdiek et al., 2022; Reddy et al., 2024). Besides image segmentation, it can also be integrated into a framework to enhance the quality and accuracy of generated scientific images.

The input to the U-Net is preprocessed to have a uniform range of flux. The flux Fxsubscript𝐹𝑥F_{x}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is normalized by the maximum flux within the input image’s 1×1⁢a⁢r⁢c⁢s⁢e⁢c11arcsec1\times 1\rm arcsec1 × 1 roman_a roman_r roman_c roman_s roman_e roman_c center area as follows:

N⁢o⁢r⁢m⁢(Fx)=Fx/max⁢(Fi⁢(1′′×1′′)).𝑁𝑜𝑟𝑚subscript𝐹𝑥subscript𝐹𝑥maxsubscript𝐹𝑖superscript1′′superscript1′′\displaystyle Norm(F_{x})=F_{x}/{\rm max}(F_{i}(1^{\prime\prime}\times 1^{% \prime\prime})).italic_N italic_o italic_r italic_m ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_max ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) . (10)

To avoid fake outputs or “hallucinations” (Ji et al., 2023), which is important for scientific applications, we will use some ‘masks’ generated by U-Net. By multiplying the masks with the input images, we aim to produce realistic output images. Our adopted procedure is shown in Fig. 3. Here, the mask generated by the U-Net represents the probability of different components in each pixel. These probabilities are positive, by definition, and they sum up to 1 by normalization. With these definitions, the flux of each component of the total signal per pixel (i.e., foreground, background, and noise), as well as the normalization of the masks, is defined as:

F^x=Fi×maskx′,subscript^𝐹𝑥subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptsuperscriptmask′x\displaystyle\hat{F}_{x}=F_{i}\times\rm mask^{\prime}_{x},over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × roman_mask start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (11)
maskx′=maskx2maskf2+maskb2+maskn2,subscriptsuperscriptmask′xsuperscriptsubscriptmaskx2superscriptsubscriptmaskf2superscriptsubscriptmaskb2superscriptsubscriptmaskn2\displaystyle\rm mask^{\prime}_{x}=\frac{mask_{x}^{2}}{mask_{f}^{2}+mask_{b}^{% 2}+mask_{n}^{2}},roman_mask start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG roman_mask start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_mask start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_mask start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_mask start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (12)

where Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the input flux of the image, maskxsubscriptmaskx\rm mask_{x}roman_mask start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the mask, and F^xsubscript^𝐹𝑥\hat{F}_{x}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the predicted flux for the foreground (f), background (b), and noise (n), i.e., x=f,b,n𝑥𝑓𝑏𝑛x=f,b,nitalic_x = italic_f , italic_b , italic_n, respectively.

As a loss function to fit the output to the different components of the lens, we use the L1 function defined as:

L1=mean⁢(∑x|F^x−Fx|),subscript𝐿1meansubscript𝑥subscript^𝐹𝑥subscript𝐹𝑥\displaystyle L_{1}=\text{mean}(\sum_{x}\left|\hat{F}_{x}-F_{x}\right|),italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = mean ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) , (13)

where F^xsubscript^𝐹𝑥\hat{F}_{x}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the predicted flux value, and Fxsubscript𝐹𝑥F_{x}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the true value of different components. The sum of the mean absolute error is used because we expect to have the same back-propagation gradients for different components. We trained the network in the PyTorch 555https://pytorch.org framework.

The training loop of the network is described in the Algorithm 1 inset. Here, the training sets consist of two kinds of data. First, the theoretical mock data, Xm=(If,Ib)∼U⁢(a,b)subscript𝑋𝑚subscript𝐼𝑓subscript𝐼𝑏similar-to𝑈𝑎𝑏X_{m}=(I_{f},I_{b})\sim U(a,b)italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∼ italic_U ( italic_a , italic_b ), are obtained by sampling their parameters from the uniform distribution listed for the foreground, background, and lens components in Table 2. Second, the real noise data, Xr=In∼S⁢u⁢r⁢v⁢e⁢ysubscript𝑋𝑟subscript𝐼𝑛similar-to𝑆𝑢𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑦X_{r}=I_{n}\sim Surveyitalic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_S italic_u italic_r italic_v italic_e italic_y, are randomly picked from observed images. Following the Algorithm 1 inset, for the mock data, we have sampled the parameters from the distribution U⁢(a,b)𝑈𝑎𝑏U(a,b)italic_U ( italic_a , italic_b ) (last three parts of Table 2), generated Ifsubscript𝐼𝑓I_{f}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ibsubscript𝐼𝑏I_{b}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and then sampled Insubscript𝐼𝑛I_{n}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the survey images. The model is trained in batches, where the augmentation parameters are sampled from U⁢(a,b)𝑈𝑎𝑏U(a,b)italic_U ( italic_a , italic_b ) (the first part of Table 2) to obtain Ff,Fb,Fnsubscript𝐹𝑓subscript𝐹𝑏subscript𝐹𝑛F_{f},F_{b},F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the training targets. As discussed in §2.3, we have used online augmentation. This means the augmented training samples are constructed “on the fly” during training. For instance, this can include image rotating or zooming. In this case, we change the magnitude, slope, and color during training.

A total of 100 000 mock images are generated and separated into 90%percent9090\%90 % for training and 10%percent1010\%10 % for validation. Another new identical mock of 1,000 images will serve as a test set to demonstrate the model performed on mock data. Fifty epochs were executed for the training. During this phase, the loss function in Eq. 13 is monitored to assess the model convergence. The training and validation losses are plotted in Fig. 4, where we can see that, after training, the loss converged to a stable value, and the checkpoints with minimal validation loss were saved.

4 Evaluation and results

In this section, we discuss the performance of the GGSL-UNet on both mock and real data. Besides evaluating the accuracy in the segmentation of the different components of the lensing systems, we will discuss how to use the ability of the GGSL-UNet to efficiently pick any strong lensing feature and the background contribution (including nearby projected random galaxies) to classify the images as lensing or non-lensing systems. We also assess the accuracy in the total flux reconstruction of the different components to produce catalogs of multi-band total magnitudes of the foreground and background systems for spectral energy distribution analyses (e.g., photometric redshifts or stellar populations).

4.1 GGSL-UNet as foreground/background/noise segmentation tool

Some examples of mock images and their reconstructed images by U-Net are shown in Fig. 5 for the KiDS mock “color” images (we do not show the HST for brevity). The images have three different components: the mock foreground galaxy Ffsubscript𝐹𝑓F_{f}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the mock background source Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the noise sample from the KiDS survey Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The corresponding parts reconstructed by U-Net are F^f,F^b,F^nsubscript^𝐹𝑓subscript^𝐹𝑏subscript^𝐹𝑛\hat{F}_{f},\hat{F}_{b},\hat{F}_{n}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here, the χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is used to evaluate the reconstruction quality, and the residuals allow us to visually assess the reconstructed results, as this should be close to the original “noise” cutout from the real data used to create the mock system.

Obviously, noise reconstruction is easier for “empty” fields with little contamination from other external sources (see Appendix A).

The χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values for each object are labeled in the corresponding panels in Fig. 5. For a lens image, one should expect χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be smaller than χ12superscriptsubscript𝜒12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the former is calculated after the background is also fitted, rather than only the foreground. This is seen in Fig. 5.

Indeed, in the figure, we can see that the U-Net can recover the geometry and color information of the foreground and background components, which usually produces χ22<2subscriptsuperscript𝜒222\chi^{2}_{2}<2italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 2. In these cases, by visually comparing the residual images, Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and F^nsubscript^𝐹𝑛\hat{F}_{n}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can see that the U-Net can reproduce the same level of noise as in the original data from the corresponding survey, demonstrating that we can extract information by properly modeling the real noise. Strikingly, the network can reconstruct very complex cases as pair-system lenses with a similar level of accuracy (see bottom row of Fig. 5, but see also Appendix A). On the other hand, we always have χ12>χ22subscriptsuperscript𝜒21subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{1}>\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT due to the presence of the background signal in the Fi−F^fsubscript𝐹𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑓F_{i}-\hat{F}_{f}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq. 14. This offers an opportunity to separate strong lensing from non-strong lensing events: indeed, by comparing χ12subscriptsuperscript𝜒21\chi^{2}_{1}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and χ22subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one can expect that reconstructions with χ12∼χ22similar-tosubscriptsuperscript𝜒21subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{1}\sim\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would correspond with a negligible contribution from background signal (either from faint source or no-source at all). We will discuss the GGSL-UNet as a tool for lens finding in §4.2.

Going back to the performances on the mock samples, to quantify the overall level of accuracy reached by the GGSL-UNet on the mock (KiDS and HST) samples, we show the distributions of the reduced χ22subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT returned by the GGSL-UNet for the KiDS-like and HST-like mock test samples in Fig. 6. Here, we can see that the χ22subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distribution of both KiDS-like and HST-like mock lenses peak at χ22∼1similar-tosubscriptsuperscript𝜒221\chi^{2}_{2}\sim 1italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ 1, with the performance of the GGSL-Unet on HST systematically better than on KiDS. The overall χ22subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distribution is also sharper for HST, with 90% of the models showing a χ22<2superscriptsubscript𝜒222\chi_{2}^{2}<2italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 2 against over 80% of the KiDS images. This demonstrates that we can successfully reconstruct the majority of mock images from ground and space. However, the latter allows the U-Net to obtain a better accuracy due to the better image quality (see, again, the discussion at the beginning of §2.3). For the systems with χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (>2absent2>2> 2), the GGSL-UNet “poorly performed” or even “failed” to reconstruct the strong lensing systems with reasonable accuracy (some large χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are attributed to the ‘companion sources’) even for the space images. These cases are discussed in Appendix A.

We have finally tested the GGSL-UNet on the real lensing systems. In Fig. 7, we show some examples of the reconstruction of the foreground/background systems and the related residuals (more examples are shown in Appendix B). In the figure, we can see the U-Net reconstruction of the two lens components, F^fsubscript^𝐹𝑓\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and F^bsubscript^𝐹𝑏\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as well as the residual F^nsubscript^𝐹𝑛\hat{F}_{n}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT images that, again, generally show a typical noise structure, including the companion/contaminant objects in the field-of-view left untouched. This illustrates how well the mock lens and the real lens foreground and background systems can be reconstructed. We stress that by properly modeling noise with U-Net, we can accurately extract the physical information of the deflector and source that are useful for science purposes (see, e.g., §4.3).

As for the mocks, also for the real systems, we can use the χ12subscriptsuperscript𝜒21\chi^{2}_{1}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and χ22subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT metrics as in Eqs. 14 and 15, where σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ represents the true photometric errors (σ−2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{-2}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the inverse variance). The χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values for each object are labeled in the corresponding panels in Fig. 7 for both KiDS and HST. In the real case, we also find generally χ12>χ22subscriptsuperscript𝜒21subscriptsuperscript𝜒22\chi^{2}_{1}>\chi^{2}_{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a difference that looks larger for larger constraint strong lensing events (as anticipated earlier), as the χ12subscriptsuperscript𝜒21\chi^{2}_{1}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is dominated by the bright residuals of bright source images left behind after the foreground galaxy has been subtracted.

To summarize the accuracy of the total sample of reconstructed “real strong lensing events,” in Fig. 6, we also show the χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT distributions of the reconstructed real lenses. Interestingly, both the real KiDS lenses and the HST lenses follow the χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT distributions of the corresponding mock samples, meaning that the quality of the reconstruction of the real lenses is similar to the one of the mock lenses. This remarkable result suggests that the GGSL-UNet is applicable to real data with no degradation of the reconstruction power despite being trained on “simulated” strong lensing systems (see §3).

4.2 GGSL-UNet as lens finding tool

We have anticipated in the previous section that comparing the χ12superscriptsubscript𝜒12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values after the reconstruction provides a possible way to detect new lens objects. The way the GGSL-UNet would work here is that it would be fed with cutouts of a generic data sample, obtaining the majority of normal “unlensed” systems, with just a foreground galaxy for which the GGSL-UNet would produce a χ12superscriptsubscript𝜒12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values from the reconstruction of the foreground and the background component.

To demonstrate how the GGSL-UNet quantitatively would react to unlensed cases, we have also applied it to a sample of normal objects. Since we only generated mock lensing systems with an elliptical foreground galaxy, we have selected some real galaxies that looked like normal ellipticals. As shown in Fig. 8, for these cases, there is no signal in F^bsubscript^𝐹𝑏\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and χ¯2≈0superscript¯𝜒20\bar{\chi}^{2}\approx 0over¯ start_ARG italic_χ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≈ 0, as expected.

To illustrate further the difference between lensed vs. unlensed systems, in Fig. 9, We plot the (χ12,χ22)superscriptsubscript𝜒12superscriptsubscript𝜒22(\chi_{1}^{2},\ \chi_{2}^{2})( italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) plane for both mock data and real KiDS data. In the left panel, we show the comparison of the χ12superscriptsubscript𝜒12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values for 1,000 mock lensed and unlensed. In the right panel, we take the 50 KiDS lens candidates and 500 randomly selected sources from the KiDS survey. As expected from Eq 16, χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should be around 1, and χ12≈χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒12superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{1}^{2}\approx\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≈ italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for unlensed images, as shown by the line-dashed envelop in the figure demonstrating a very small scatter (obviously, χ12superscriptsubscript𝜒12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is much larger than χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the lensing systems). Due to the higher SNR in the mock data compared to the real data and the weaker background signal in the lens candidates, the χ12superscriptsubscript𝜒12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values in the real data are much smaller than those in the mock data, but still significantly deviating from the 1-to-1 relation.

For completeness, in Fig. 10, we have compared the results of the U-Net vs the the BELLS GALLERY ray-tracing model for the HST real galaxies face-to-face. This offers the opportunity to check the GGSL-UNet performances against some standard tool (as in Shu et al. 2016). Note that, here, we are not asking the GGSL-UNet to derive the lens model parameters (the Einstein radius, axis ratio mass density, etc.) as the ray-tracing models do, but just compare the “residuals” after the image reconstruction from the U-Net using the same χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT metrics for both the U-Net and the BELLS GALLERY ray-tracing model.

The figure shows that the χ12superscriptsubscript𝜒12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the two methods is similar, i.e., that they model the foreground galaxy with similar accuracy. However, on the left-behind signal (i.e., the background + noise after the foreground subtraction), the GGSL-UNet largely outperforms the standard ray-tracing modeling, keeping for all systems a χ22∼1similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜒221\chi_{2}^{2}\sim 1italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ 1 or smaller. The BELLS GALLERY sample has a mean χ22=2.70superscriptsubscript𝜒222.70\chi_{2}^{2}=2.70italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2.70 (after the full model subtraction), while the GGSL-UNet has a mean χ22=0.75superscriptsubscript𝜒220.75\chi_{2}^{2}=0.75italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.75. The reconstructed images and residuals are compared in Appendix B for some systems for a visual comparison. This result is likely due to the ability of the U-Net to separate the background signal from the noise without being dominated by the model errors and degeneracies. This opens two very promising perspectives: 1) that the generative models, or similar deep learning networks, can be used to more efficiently isolate the background signal for more accurate modeling using standard techniques, or 2) that one can use the GGSL-UNet itself to infer the main lens parameters.

4.3 GGSL-UNet as photometry reconstruction tool

In image segmentation or de-noising, an exquisite χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not guarantee that the signal segmentation (as in Eq. 1) is degeneracy-free. Since one of the great advantages of our method is the possibility to integrate the signal associated with every component to derive total fluxes, we need to demonstrate that the U-Net output images can preserve the flux information in every band and, consequently, the color information in multi-band catalogs. This is of paramount importance for science applications. One classic example is the derivation of the photometric redshifts, where the multi-band photometry and colors are fitted to theoretical or observational templates of galaxies to derive the redshift (see, e.g., 𝐿𝑒𝑃𝐻𝐴𝑅𝐸𝐿𝑒𝑃𝐻𝐴𝑅𝐸\it LePHAREitalic_LePHARE, Arnouts et al. 1999; Ilbert et al. 2006). We will show such an application to the KiDS photometry derived with GGSL-UNet in Appendix C. Another example is using the multi-band photometric information of the source and the deflector to derive stellar population parameters (see, e.g., Li et al. 2023). Hence, we need to investigate the photometry accuracy that one can derive from the flux breakdown in all image pixels as described in §3. Obviously, this can only be done for the mock samples for which the ‘ground truth’ magnitudes are known. We remark here that, as we use real noise background cutouts, we expect these, combined with the lensed source signal, to dominate the photometric errors, thus providing a realistic assessment of the overall precision of the reconstructed magnitudes. Also, we concentrate only on the KiDS sample for two reasons: 1) it is the only dataset for which we have the color information (the BELL GALERY sample has only one band), and 2) it is the worst-case scenario as we have seen that, for HST, the reconstruction is always better so we can use the ground-based observation as an upper limit on the photometric accuracy reachable for the strong lensing reconstruction with GGSL-UNet. The magnitudes of the input and output mock images are then simply defined as666https://kids.strw.leidenuniv.nl/DR4/format.php:

mx=−2.5⁢log10⁢∑(x,y)=(0,0)(64,64)F^x,subscript𝑚𝑥2.5subscript10superscriptsubscriptxy006464subscript^𝐹𝑥\displaystyle m_{x}=-2.5\log_{10}\sum_{\rm(x,y)=(0,0)}^{(64,64)}\hat{F}_{x},italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 2.5 roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_x , roman_y ) = ( 0 , 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 64 , 64 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (17)

for every component x=f,b,n𝑥𝑓𝑏𝑛x=f,b,nitalic_x = italic_f , italic_b , italic_n as discussed in §3. Fig. 11 top panel shows the accuracy for the four band magnitudes of the foreground and background components of the KiDS mocks, using this definition, while the bottom panel shows the same results for the HST mocks. The x-axis represents the magnitudes for the mock (precisely Ffsubscript𝐹𝑓F_{f}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the full or empty symbols, respectively), while the y-axis represents the difference between the output and input magnitudes for F^fsubscript^𝐹𝑓\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or F^bsubscript^𝐹𝑏\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (symbols as above). In the same figure, we show the distributions of the input-output magnitudes that allow us to highlight the presence of systematics. From this figure, we can derive two main features.

First, looking at the input-output distributions, for KiDS, there are almost no systematics for the foreground magnitudes (median Mf∼0.03similar-tosubscript𝑀𝑓0.03M_{f}\sim 0.03italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ 0.03 and scatter σf∼0.11similar-tosubscript𝜎𝑓0.11\sigma_{f}\sim 0.11italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ 0.11 across the different bands, as in the inset), although we also observe a tail toward the positive deviation (overestimate). Such an overestimate is more evident for the background magnitudes: here, the offset has a median Mb∼0.08similar-tosubscript𝑀𝑏0.08M_{b}\sim 0.08italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ 0.08 and scatter σb∼0.35similar-tosubscript𝜎𝑏0.35\sigma_{b}\sim 0.35italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ 0.35. For HST, there is no bias for both foreground and background magnitudes (M<0.003𝑀0.003M<0.003italic_M < 0.003, i.e., smaller than typical photometric calibration errors) with a scatter that is ∼80%similar-toabsentpercent80\sim 80\%∼ 80 % smaller than the corresponding KiDS r𝑟ritalic_r-band for the background magnitude, while it is only half of the precision of KiDS foreground photometry.

Second, looking at the input-output vs. input magnitude plot, for KiDS, the foreground galaxies have magnitudes that are recovered within 1σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ, especially for mag>21absent21>21> 21, and the median deviation is always contained within ∼similar-to\sim∼0.05 mag in all bands (except for very bright sources at mag<19absent19<19< 19 that show a positive offset marginally consistent with zero within 1σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ). The background source magnitudes, instead, are systematically overestimated by ∼similar-to\sim∼0.1 mag. At a very close look, one may also see a trend to increase the offset for the background magnitude and decrease the offset for the foreground magnitudes toward fainter magnitudes (see comment below). There are no trends for HST, and all magnitudes are very accurately recovered by the U-Net. This shows a superiority of the predictions in space observations vs. ground-based observation in general, which might come from the better image quality (see below).

In principle, one can foresee that the presence of these systematics for the background photometry can impact the quantities that are based on total fluxes (luminosities, stellar masses, etc.) as the fainter systems (typically higher redshifts or less magnified galaxies) would result fainter and less massive than they really are. As this trend with the magnitudes is similar in all bands, this does not seem to affect the colors. Hence, one can argue that these systematics would have less impact on the quantities based on colors (e.g., the photometric redshifts).

Besides registering these potential systematics, we should try to assess the origin of these offsets here to elaborate strategies for future improvements. In this respect, the fact that both foreground and background systems are overestimated, regardless of the intrinsic magnitude, means that there is some flux missing from the U-Net segmentation as in Eq. 1. While one can expect that this should be easy to predict in the high-SNR pixels, this might become difficult at the low-SNR, where the signal is overwhelmed by the noise. In these pixels, we can argue that the GGSL-Unet tends to overweight the noise and subtracts flux to either the background, foreground, or both. As a partial demonstration of that, we have tested if the offset is alleviated using sharper surface brightness profiles for both foreground and background, setting the n𝑛nitalic_n-index to stay within [1-4] and limiting the q>0.4𝑞0.4q>0.4italic_q > 0.4 to reduce the degeneracies among the parameters in the reconstruction. In this case, the offset for the foreground and the background systems reduced to 0.010.010.010.01 and 0.070.070.070.07 with a scatter of 0.1 and 0.2, respectively, hence suggesting a noticeable improvement. Currently, to keep the parameter space as wide as possible, we decided to live with these systematics for the KiDS reconstructed photometry, keeping in mind that they have to be related to the structure of the noise in KiDS. Indeed, this effect is not seen in the HST images (see bottom panel of Fig. 11). According to the discussion above, we can explain this with the fact that, first, for HST images, the SNR is much higher than in KiDS and, second, the PSF in HST is sharper, and then the quality is higher than in the KiDS observations, making even the smoother light profiles easier for the U-Net to detect and then reconstruct the related image.

5 Discussion and conclusion

In this paper, we have applied the generative network U-Net to reconstruct different components of galaxy-galaxy strong lensing images, namely the foreground (f𝑓fitalic_f) deflector light, the deformed image of the background source (b𝑏bitalic_b), either arc-like or multiple-imaged, and the noise (n𝑛nitalic_n), usually denoted as “sky background.” The tool for this Galaxy-Galaxy Strong lensing reconstruction using U-Net (GGSL-UNet for short) has been applied to high-quality strong lensing candidates from the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS) and for a sample of HST-confirmed strong lensing events fully modeled within the BELLS GALLERY project.

The GGSL-UNet’s main feature is the generation of masks that represent different “weights” for the contribution from the foreground, background, and noise to each pixel’s flux. The network has been trained on realistic training samples that we have constructed by combining noise (i.e., sky background) samples from different real survey data with theoretical mock foreground and background models, assumed to follow Sérsic profiles, which we have further improved by taking advantage of online augmentation. Using an appropriate L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT loss function to guide the U-Net in fitting different components —- especially the noise -— in the training data, we have optimized the performances of the U-Net in extracting the signals for the foreground and background systems. Despite the fact that the light densities from the f𝑓fitalic_f/b𝑏bitalic_b components are rather idealized (single Sérsic profile, no substructures, etc.), the U-Net could still learn how to accurately model the real noise, allowing the network to extract these signals correctly.

By modeling the multi-color band images of KiDS, we have demonstrated that a well-trained U-Net network can reproduce the foreground and background components for both mock and real data. The color and geometry information in the images are well retained in the reconstructed components. The U-Net performs well even in low SNR situations, with a χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (defined in §4.2) remaining within reasonable values. For cases with no strong lensing signatures, the U-Net could still model the foreground source very effectively, indicating that the generative network can also be used as a source extraction tool (see, e.g., SExtractor, Bertin & Arnouts 1996).

The GGSL-UNet used to reconstruct different components of the HST r𝑟ritalic_r-band images differs from the one used for KiDS strong lenses, mainly for the noise component and the different PSF adopted to convolve the Sérsic models of both the foreground (deflector) and the background (source) galaxies. We have compared the reconstructed components with the BELLS GALLERY models (see Appendix B) and found that the U-Net reconstruction shows an accuracy comparable to classical methods. Comparing the mean χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we demonstrate that GGSL-UNet has a better overall performance in reconstructing the total luminosity from the two strong lensing components, foreground+background, as shown in Fig. 10.

In addition to the segmentation of strong lensing events, we have also shown other possible applications of the network to other typical tasks to be performed in large imaging surveys like denoising images and extracting sources as illustrated in Fig. 8 and searching for lenses as shown in Fig. 9.

For Strong lensing, the GGSL-UNet has an extreme potential to be improved further. It can be applied to different kinds of sources by using different training samples in different survey data. For instance, we can model AGN as background sources, as well as implement more complex Sérsic models or the Nuker model (Graham et al., 2003) to improve the reconstruction power of the U-Net in space-based observations, or we can add more realistic contaminants in the training sample, such as spiral galaxies.

Even in the current basic version, the GGSL-UNet output is expected to represent a crucial step for strong lensing modeling if used in combination with standard MCMC or other deep learning tools such as LEMON (Gentile et al., 2023) to determine the corresponding strong lensing parameters, which is considered a downstream task for sophisticated analysis in the current all-sky surveys where hundreds or thousands of these events are expected to be found.

With this paper, we have started by demonstrating the effectiveness of lens image decomposition and photometry reconstruction under different noise conditions (ground-based KIDS and space-based HST). For the upcoming data from ground-based surveys, such as LSST, Wide Field Survey Telescope (WFST, Wang et al. 2023), and space-based surveys, such as Euclid (Laureijs et al., 2011), Roman (Spergel et al., 2015), and the China Space Station Telescope surveys, our tools will provide high-quality images for lens modeling and multi-band photometry reconstruction of both deflector and source.
