Appendix A Anomaly cases

In §4, we have used the χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT metrics to assess the quality of the GGSL-Unet reconstruction, and we have seen that despite the majority of cases showing a χ22<2superscriptsubscript𝜒222\chi_{2}^{2}<2italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 2, ∼20%similar-toabsentpercent20\sim 20\%∼ 20 % of KiDS models and ∼10%similar-toabsentpercent10\sim 10\%∼ 10 % of HST models showed a larger χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We stress here (as anticipated in §3) that, by construction, the χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT value can be strongly influenced by the structure of the “noise” image, as strong substructures in its flux (Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), which would be difficult to reconstruct by the U-Net, and then produce larger χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, high χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not generally mean bad reconstruction, as we will show below. On the other hand, there are situations where high χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values come from bad reconstructions. Here, we want to look into the different cases to check whether there are avenues for improvements or if there are pathological cases we need to live with.

We start by showing some of the mock objects with large χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values in Fig. 12, where we can distinguish the following cases:

  1. 1.

    Pair of foreground galaxies. Despite the fact that the GGSL-Unet can generally model these cases (see §4.1), which are contemplated in the training sample, there are still cases where the reconstruction is not optimal. This is shown in rows 1 and 2 of Fig. 12, where we can see the GGSL-Unet can still fit the foreground properly but with a poorer χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Very bright “companion” objects (e.g., bright stars). In Rows 3 and 4 of Fig. 12, the very bright objects located very close to or even overlapping with the lens strongly impact the χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, although both the foreground and the background images are nicely reconstructed.

  3. 3.

    Low SNR arcs. In Rows 5 and 6 of Fig. 12, the background signal level is low, and most of them are overwhelmed by noise, but U-Net can still reconstruct the geometry roughly.

The “failed” cases are instead shown in Fig. 13. Here, we can also distinguish different situations:

  1. 1.

    Corrupted images. In Rows 1 and 2 of Fig. 13, Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is randomly selected from the KiDS survey, and the edges of tiles or artificial signals make the image broken. Surprisingly, the reconstruction in Row 1 seems reasonably good (despite the large χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT due to the irregular “noise” structure).

  2. 2.

    Crowded fields. In Rows 3 and 4 of 13, the weak background signal and the presence of external sources may cause the incorrect reconstruction of the background galaxy.

  3. 3.

    False positive candidates. In the last two rows of Fig 13, we show some no-lensing systems. Due to the absence of a background signal and heavy noise, some noise is misinterpreted as a background signal.

To summarise, anomalous χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT generally imply a bad reconstruction, but, as shown in this appendix, they might also indicate a complex “noise” (i.e., sky background) structure. This latter case is generally true for ground-based observations, while the sharper image of space observations provides a smoother noise structure. As a strategy for practical application, one can foresee an inspection of the large χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cases (either using human eyeball checks or deep learning algorithm) to retain the cases with good Ffsubscript𝐹𝑓F_{f}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reconstructions.

Appendix B More lens reconstruction

We show 20 KiDS lens candidates in Fig. 14. The χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and residuals indicate that the foreground and background components generated by U-Net are well-modeled. Most lens candidates here have low SNR, and some have extra sources besides the foreground and background components. In some cases, the foreground and background sources are very close to each other, but the U-Net can still model them very well. One issue is that the U-Net might misinterpret the arm of a spiral galaxy as a background arc. We believe this can be resolved by introducing more relevant spiral foreground training samples to the network.

We also show the 8 BELLS GALLERY images (only r𝑟ritalic_r-band) reconstructed by the U-Net in Fig. 15. Differently from the KiDS cases, here we can compare the GGSL-Unet reconstruction with the ray-tracing model by Shu et al. (2016). Columns 2 and 4 in the figure represent models of standard classical ray-tracing methods. We include them here to compare the deep learning and traditional MCMC-based classical methods. By comparing the χ22superscriptsubscript𝜒22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can claim that the U-Net modeling achieves at least the same level of accuracy as the classical method, and in some cases, it performs even better.

Appendix C Downstream task: Photometric redshift

In §4, we have demonstrated that 1) the U-Net can effectively denoise and “decouple” the foreground galaxy and background components from the input lens image; 2) the U-Net can also reconstruct the intrinsic photometry of the strong lensing components, although, for the ground-based observations, there are systematic offsets between estimated magnitudes and true values.

To illustrate a practical application of the GGSL-Unet output, we have estimated the photometric redshift as a downstream task. We calculate the magnitude of different bands from reconstructed fore/background images and obtain the photometric redshift for both components.

The aperture magnitude of the foreground and background sources are approximately calculated following Eq. 17. In Fig. 16, we plot the foreground and background magnitudes, mfsubscript𝑚𝑓m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are calculated using the reconstructed optical band flux F^fsubscript^𝐹𝑓\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and F^bsubscript^𝐹𝑏\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, versus the KiDS catalog magnitude, MAG_GAaP in Table 1. Here, we have corrected mfsubscript𝑚𝑓m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for extinction, as has already been done for the KiDS catalog magnitudes (MAG_GAaP, see Kuijken et al. 2019). The mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is much larger than mfsubscript𝑚𝑓m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as expected, since most of the lens candidates in the dataset have lower flux compared to the foreground galaxy. Considering that the foreground flux is difficult to distinguish from the background and noise when the flux is low, we have additionally applied a correction for the foreground, using the flux inside the 95% flux contour of F^fsubscript^𝐹𝑓\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. One would expect mfsubscript𝑚𝑓m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to approximate MAG_GAaP, but it is slightly larger in the u𝑢uitalic_u band. As MAG_GAaP is derived from galaxy shapes and position angles, the GAaP method may not be able to distinguish between the lens and arcs in low SNR images, such as those in the u𝑢uitalic_u-band. Consequently, MAG_GAaP values for u𝑢uitalic_u-band images might include contributions from both the lens and the background galaxy. Because the flux F^fsubscript^𝐹𝑓\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only includes the flux of the foreground, we calculate the total flux of the foreground, F^fsubscript^𝐹𝑓\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and background, F^bsubscript^𝐹𝑏\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The magnitude is then calculated using Eq 17, and the results are shown in Fig. 17. The figure shows that the u𝑢uitalic_u-band matches better when considering both foreground and background flux, but the u𝑢uitalic_u-band magnitudes are still slightly overestimated in this case. Nonetheless, it demonstrates that the background image contributes a significant portion of the u𝑢uitalic_u-band flux. This is consistent with the physical scenario of the lens where the foreground galaxy is redder while the background is bluer.

From the figure, we can see that for the foreground, the g𝑔gitalic_g, r𝑟ritalic_r, and i𝑖iitalic_i magnitudes are well reproduced by the U-Net output. However, the deviation in the u𝑢uitalic_u-band magnitude is considerably larger. This is because the u𝑢uitalic_u-band flux is much smaller than the other redder bands, making the noise and background contribute much higher than in other bands, hence causing larger relative error.

Due to the large uncertainties in the u𝑢uitalic_u-band magnitude, we predict the foreground redshift using the remaining bands, g𝑔gitalic_g, r𝑟ritalic_r, and i𝑖iitalic_i. We match the corresponding targets with the spectroscopic measurements and use the spectroscopic redshift as the ground truth. In Fig. 18, we demonstrate the foreground photometric redshift estimated by 𝐿𝑒𝑃𝐻𝐴𝑅𝐸𝐿𝑒𝑃𝐻𝐴𝑅𝐸\it LePHAREitalic_LePHARE versus the spectroscopic redshift. 𝐿𝑒𝑃𝐻𝐴𝑅𝐸𝐿𝑒𝑃𝐻𝐴𝑅𝐸\it LePHAREitalic_LePHARE photo-z𝑧zitalic_zhave been obtained using stellar templates from Bruzual & Charlot (2003) with a Chabrier (2003) initial mass function (IMF) and an exponentially decaying star formation history. The photometric redshift is calculated using magnitudes either provided by the KiDS catalog or derived from Eq. 17 using U-Net outputs. As mentioned for the foreground galaxy, we have estimated the photometric redshift using only the magnitudes of three bands (g⁢r⁢i𝑔𝑟𝑖griitalic_g italic_r italic_i). However, for comparison, we have also estimated the photometric redshift using 9-band magnitudes, adding the near-infrared (NIR) magnitudes from Z⁢Y⁢H⁢J⁢Ks𝑍𝑌𝐻𝐽subscript𝐾𝑠ZYHJK_{s}italic_Z italic_Y italic_H italic_J italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the KiDS/VIKING catalog (see again Kuijken et al. 2019). We also use other data combinations, like the u⁢g⁢r⁢i𝑢𝑔𝑟𝑖ugriitalic_u italic_g italic_r italic_i magnitudes from U-Net combined with the Z⁢Y⁢J⁢H⁢KS𝑍𝑌𝐽𝐻subscript𝐾𝑆ZYJHK_{S}italic_Z italic_Y italic_J italic_H italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT magnitudes from the KiDS. The different photo-z𝑧zitalic_z estimates of the foreground galaxy from the photometric combinations above are shown in Fig. 18. Here, we can clearly see that the photo-z𝑧zitalic_z based on optical band only is very poorly estimated (scatter δ=0.14𝛿0.14\delta=0.14italic_δ = 0.14) as compared to the full 9-band photometry for which we have found a scatter δ=0.05𝛿0.05\delta=0.05italic_δ = 0.05 and all estimates aligned along the 1-to-1 relation. However, we can see that the GGSL-Unet photometry also allowed us to obtain similar accuracy and precision (δ=0.06𝛿0.06\delta=0.06italic_δ = 0.06) of the 9-band KiDS photometry, showing a substantial consistency for the foreground galaxy and the reliability of our photometry reconstruction in the optical bands, although we have assessed the presence of systematics of 0.03 mag (see §4.3).

To make the U-Net model fully multi-band (from optical to NIR) and possibly achieve higher accuracy in redshift estimation, we need to incorporate additional infrared bands into the U-Net training. This is one of the next steps of our project for upcoming papers.

This important implementation will be fundamental for accurate photo-z of the background sources. To derive the integrated photometry of the background galaxies in the optica+NIR, we also need the GGSL-Unet to perform in NIR images. Currently, we have tried to assess the accuracy of the photo-z𝑧zitalic_z based only on the U-Net optical photometry. This is shown in Fig. 19, where the background redshift estimated using four optical bands (u⁢g⁢r⁢i𝑢𝑔𝑟𝑖ugriitalic_u italic_g italic_r italic_i) is plotted against the spectroscopic redshift of the foreground as a sanity check. Here, we have also considered the u𝑢uitalic_u-band in the photo-z𝑧zitalic_z determination, despite the systematics discussed above, but not as severe for the background source as the foreground.

The figure shows that the majority of the photo-z𝑧zitalic_z of the background source is larger than the spectroscopic redshift of the foreground system, hence suggesting that this is compatible with a lensing system. We want to stress that if we can determine the background redshift, we can further distinguish whether the candidates are true lenses or just spiral/diffuse galaxies because the background redshift should be larger than the foreground spec-z or photo-z. In contrast, spiral or diffuse galaxies have similar foreground and background redshifts. On the other hand, for ∼15similar-toabsent15\sim 15∼ 15 systems (i.e., ∼30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\%∼ 30 % of the full catalog), the photo-z𝑧zitalic_z of the source is similar if not smaller than the spec-z𝑧zitalic_z of the deflector, suggesting that these photo-z𝑧zitalic_z are likely to be wrong.
